messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Almost Polynomial Factor Inapproximability for Parameterized 𝑘-Clique

Paper Abstract: Abstract The k𝑘k-Clique problem is a canonical hard problem in parameterized complexity. In this paper, we study the parameterized complexity of approximating the k𝑘k-Clique problem where an integer k𝑘k and a graph G𝐺G on n𝑛n vertices are given as input, and the goal is to find a clique of size at least k/F​(k)𝑘𝐹𝑘k/F(k) whenever the graph G𝐺G has a clique of size k𝑘k. When such an algorithm runs in time T​(k)⋅poly​(n)⋅𝑇𝑘poly𝑛T(k)\cdot\text{poly}(n) (i.e., FPT-time) for some computable function T𝑇T, it is said to be an F​(k)𝐹𝑘F(k)-FPT-approximation algorithm for the k𝑘k-Clique problem. Although, the non-existence of an F​(k)𝐹𝑘F(k)-FPT-approximation algorithm for any computable sublinear function F𝐹F is known under gap-ETH [Chalermsook et al., FOCS 2017], it has remained a long standing open problem to prove the same inapproximability result under the more standard and weaker assumption, W[1]≠\neqFPT. In a recent breakthrough, Lin [STOC 2021] ruled out constant factor (i.e., F​(k)=O​(1)𝐹𝑘𝑂1F(k)=O(1)) FPT-approximation algorithms under W[1]≠\neqFPT. In this paper, we improve this inapproximability result (under the same assumption) to rule out every F​(k)=k1/H​(k)𝐹𝑘superscript𝑘1𝐻𝑘F(k)=k^{1/H(k)} factor FPT-approximation algorithm for any increasing computable function H𝐻H (for example H​(k)=log∗⁡k𝐻𝑘superscript∗𝑘H(k)=\log^{\ast}k). Our main technical contribution is introducing list decoding of Hadamard codes over large prime fields into the proof framework of Lin.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Proof verification and the hardness of approximation problems",
        "On the parameterized complexity of k-sum",
        "Probabilistic checking of proofs: A new characterization of NP",
        "Improved low-degree testing and its applications",
        "Parameterized intractability of even set and shortest vector problem",
        "On subexponential and fpt-time inapproximability",
        "Parameterized intractability of even set and shortest vector problem from gap-eth",
        "Efficient probabilistically checkable proofs and applications to approximations",
        "Free bits, pcps, and nonapproximability-towards tight results",
        "Applications of random algebraic constructions to hardness of approximation",
        "Self-testing/correcting with applications to numerical problems",
        "On the complexity of approximating the independent set problem",
        "Improved non-approximability results",
        "From gap-eth to fpt-inapproximability: Clique, dominating set, and more",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "On parameterized approximability",
        "Fixed-parameter and approximation algorithms: A new look",
        "On the computational hardness based on linear fpt-reductions",
        "Strong computational lower bounds via parameterized complexity",
        "The constant inapproximability of the parameterized dominating set problem",
        "Fixed-parameter tractability and completeness II: on completeness for W[1]",
        "Fundamentals of Parameterized Complexity",
        "Parameterized approximation problems",
        "The PCP theorem by gap amplification",
        "Mildly exponential reduction from gap 3sat to polynomial-gap label-cover",
        "On the complexity of fixed parameter clique and dominating set",
        "Clique is hard to approximate within n1-o(1)1-o(1){}^{\\mbox{1-\\emph{o}(1)}}",
        "Approximating maximum clique by removing subgraphs",
        "Interactive proofs and the hardness of approximating cliques",
        "Two-prover protocols - low error at affordable rates",
        "A survey on approximation in parameterized complexity: Hardness and algorithms",
        "A hard-core predicate for all one-way functions",
        "Learning polynomials with queries: The highly noisy case",
        "List decoding of binary codes-a brief survey of some recent results",
        "Clique is hard to approximate within n1-epsilon1-epsilon{}^{\\mbox{1-epsilon}}",
        "Testing of the long code and hardness for clique",
        "The foundations of fixed parameter inapproximability",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "Improved inaproximability results for maxclique, chromatic number and approximate graph coloring",
        "On the parameterized complexity of approximating dominating set",
        "On hardness of approximation of parameterized set cover and label cover: Threshold graphs from error correcting codes",
        "Better inapproximability results for maxclique, chromatic number and min-3lin-deletion",
        "A two-prover one-round game with strong soundness",
        "The parameterized complexity of the k-biclique problem",
        "A simple gap-producing reduction for the parameterized set cover problem",
        "Constant approximating k-clique is w[1]-hard",
        "On lower bounds of approximating parameterized k-clique",
        "Parameterized complexity and approximability of directed odd cycle transversal",
        "Parameterized complexity and approximation algorithms",
        "A birthday repetition theorem and complexity of approximating dense csps",
        "On the complexity of the subgraph problem",
        "Optimization, approximation, and complexity classes",
        "A parallel repetition theorem",
        "What’s next? Future directions in parameterized complexity",
        "Parameterized inapproximability for steiner orientation by gap amplification",
        "Linear degree extractors and the inapproximability of max clique and chromatic number"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Almost Polynomial Factor Inapproximability for Parameterized 𝑘-Clique, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
